message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cherry-red macular spot and onion-skin appearance of lysosomes suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Ceramide trihexoside accumulation causes Fabry disease, sphingomyelin accumulation causes Niemann-Pick disease type A and B, and glucocerebroside accumulation causes Gaucher disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and the cherry-red macular spot suggest GM2 gangliosidosis, specifically Tay-Sachs disease. The onion-skin appearance of lysosomes is a characteristic finding in Tay-Sachs disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of symptoms suggests Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the lysosomes. The other options are associated with different lysosomal storage disorders.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a cherry-red macular spot and onion-skin appearance in lysosomes suggest GM2 ganglioside accumulation, which is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease. Ceramide trihexoside accumulation is seen in Fabry disease, sphingomyelin accumulation is seen in Niemann-Pick disease, and glucocerebroside accumulation is seen in Gaucher disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presence of a cherry-red macular spot and lysosomes with an onion-skin appearance suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by an accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Accumulation of ceramide trihexoside is seen in Fabry disease, accumulation of sphingomyelin is seen in Niemann-Pick disease, and accumulation of glucocerebroside is seen in Gaucher disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cherry-red macular spot and loss of developmental milestones suggest a diagnosis of Tay-Sachs disease. Tay-Sachs disease is caused by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside in the lysosomes of neurons. This is due to a deficiency in the enzyme hexosaminidase A.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cherry-red macular spot, loss of developmental milestones, and onion-skin appearance of lysosomes suggest Tay-Sachs disease, which is caused by accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Ceramide trihexoside accumulation causes Fabry disease, sphingomyelin accumulation causes Niemann-Pick disease, and glucocerebroside accumulation causes Gaucher disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The combination of cherry-red macular spot and loss of developmental milestones suggests lysosomal storage disorder. The onion-skin appearance of lysosomes points to GM2 ganglioside accumulation, which is characteristic of Tay-Sachs disease. Accumulation of ceramide trihexoside is seen in Fabry disease, sphingomyelin in Niemann-Pick disease, and glucocerebroside in Gaucher disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cherry-red macular spot and onion-skin appearance of lysosomes are characteristic findings in GM2 gangliosidosis (Tay-Sachs disease), which is caused by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Ceramide trihexoside accumulation leads to Fabry disease, sphingomyelin accumulation leads to Niemann-Pick disease, and glucocerebroside accumulation leads to Gaucher disease, but none of these conditions present with the cherry-red macular spot.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The cherry-red macular spot and the onion-skin appearance of lysosomes suggest Tay-Sachs disease. This disease is caused by the accumulation of GM2 ganglioside. Accumulation of ceramide trihexoside is seen in Fabry disease, accumulation of sphingomyelin is seen in Niemann-Pick disease, and accumulation of glucocerebroside is seen in Gaucher disease.
